A Vandermonde matrix is usually taken to have rows of the form (1,a,a2,...an−1)(1, a, a^2, ... a^{n-1})(1,a,a2,...an−1), but it is also in some contexts  mathematically meaningful to allow extra rows of the form (0,...,0,1)(0, ..., 0, 1)(0,...,0,1), which can be thought of as scalings of the row with a=∞a = \inftya=∞.

#22377 defines a new type of matrix vandermondeTop which allows this extra type of row, gives a formula for their determinant, and proves that (like vandermonde matrices) they are nonsingular iff the rows are distinct.
It also expands the docstring to briefly describe the contexts in which these matrices arise.

Everything is happening in the Vandermonde leaf file.
Even though we don't use any WithTop API, we chose WithTop rather than Option to describe the row function, because of the natural mathematical interpretation of the extra type of row.

Would it be reasonable to generalize it to rows of the form (bn−1,bn−2a,…,ban−2,an−1)(b^{n-1}, b^{n-2}a, \ldots, b a^{n-2}, a^{n-1})(bn−1,bn−2a,…,ban−2,an−1)? This looks like a "projective versus affine" thing to me.
(Disclaimer: I have not looked at the PR.)
I've never seen this, but it makes perfect sense now you mention it!
Instead of the monomials of a univariate polynomial of degree <n< n<n, you look at the monomials of a bivariate homogeneous polynomial of degree n−1n-1n−1.
Yes - this is quite lovely, and will give me a way to avoid Option and its synonyms entirely.

Ok, I'm in a bit of an annoying situation. The formula for the determinant of the 'projective' Vandermonde matrix with rows (bin−1,aibin−2,…,ain−1)(b_i^{n-1}, a_ib_i^{n-2}, \dotsc, a_i^{n-1})(bin−1​,ai​bin−2​,…,ain−1​) is Π0≤i<j<n(ajbi−aibj)\Pi_{0 \le i < j < n} (a_jb_i - a_ib_j)Π0≤i<j<n​(aj​bi​−ai​bj​) which is very nice, and specializes easily to the normal Vandermonde determinant formula in the case where bbb is the all-ones vector.

To prove this generalized formula, one could either

  1. generalize the existing proof of the nonprojective determinant formula to the projective version (and then derive the original version as a special case), or
  2. apply the nonprojective determinant formula to the matrix with rows (1,ci,ci2,…,cin−1)(1, c_i, c_i^2, \dotsc, c_i^{n-1})(1,ci​,ci2​,…,cin−1​) with ci=ai/bic_i = a_i / b_ici​=ai​/bi​ and use scalings to compute the original determinant.

Option 2 has a few disadvantages - it unnecessarily requires a field rather than a ring, and involves some annoying indexing case-split nonsense for rows where bi=0b_i = 0bi​=0. It is possible to do it this way, but I'd rather avoid it.

Option 1 is the 'right' way, but unfortunately the existing proof involves some matrix determinant manipulation that would involve a division by bib_ibi​ in the generalization, which give problems when bib_ibi​ is a zero divisor. And the other proofs of the Vandermonde determinant identity that I can find all use things that require at least a domain when generalized. So I don't know how to do option 1 in a way that allows for the original nonprojective determinant formula to be recovered in full generality.

One approach might be to work in a domain R+R^+R+ of which the ring RRR is a homomorphic image, then use the fact that the homomorphism commutes with determinants to obtain the result for RRR. My abstract algebra is abysmal, but googling suggests this should be possible by choosing R+R^+R+ to be some free ring. Can anyone with knowledge of such things tell me if this is correct, and currently possible in mathlib?

One workaround is to define R:=Z[A0,B0,A1,B1,…,An−1,Bn−1]R:=\Z[A_0,B_0,A_1,B_1,\ldots,A_{n-1},B_{n-1}]R:=Z[A0​,B0​,A1​,B1​,…,An−1​,Bn−1​] (an integral domain) and let KKK be the field of fractions of RRR (a field). You can prove the result for the matrix made by the AiA_iAi​ and BjB_jBj​ over KKK (note that Bi≠0B_i\not=0Bi​=0 as it's a polynomial variable), deduce it over RRR and then deduce it over an arbitrary ring using the standard fact that if you have a homomorphism of rings and a matrix with coefficients in the source, then the det of the pushforward matrix is the pushforward of the det ("pushforward" means "apply the homomorphism"). The point is that given any ring S and any a_i, b_j in S, there's a map from R to S sending A_i to a_i and B_j to b_j. The ring R is "universal" for the question: if you prove the det result for R then it's true for any ring.
I'm not claiming that this will be easy, but on paper at least it is a way of getting around several of the things you're worried about.

It wasn't so bad! 

import Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.FractionRing
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Vandermonde

open Fin

variable {n : ℕ} {R K : Type*} [CommRing R] [Field K]

def projVandermonde (v w : Fin n → R) : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) R :=
  .of fun i j ↦ (v i)^(j : ℕ) * (w i)^(Fin.rev j : ℕ)

theorem projVandermonde_map {R' : Type*} [CommRing R'] (φ : R →+* R') (v w : Fin n → R) :
    projVandermonde (fun i ↦ φ (v i)) (fun i ↦ φ (w i)) = φ.mapMatrix (projVandermonde v w) := by
  ext i j
  simp [projVandermonde]

private theorem projVandermonde_det_of_field (v w : Fin n → K) : (projVandermonde v w).det =
    ∏ i : Fin n, ∏ j ∈ Finset.Ioi i, ((v j * w i) - (v i * w j)) := by
  sorry

theorem projVandermonde_det (v w : Fin n → R) : (projVandermonde v w).det =
    ∏ i : Fin n, ∏ j ∈ Finset.Ioi i, (v j * w i - v i * w j) := by
  let R' := MvPolynomial (Fin n × Bool) ℤ
  let u : Fin n × Bool → FractionRing R' := fun i ↦ (algebraMap R' _) (MvPolynomial.X ⟨i.1, i.2⟩)
  have hdet := projVandermonde_det_of_field (u ⟨· , true⟩) (u ⟨·, false⟩)
  simp only [u, RingHom.mapMatrix_apply] at hdet
  norm_cast at hdet
  rw [projVandermonde_map, ← RingHom.map_det, IsFractionRing.coe_inj] at hdet
  apply_fun MvPolynomial.eval₂Hom (Int.castRingHom R) (fun x ↦ (if x.2 then v else w) x.1) at hdet
  rw [RingHom.map_det] at hdet
  convert hdet <;>
  simp [← Matrix.ext_iff, projVandermonde, u, R']

Thanks for the merge, @Johan Commelin !

I've now removed the WIP label and updated the design to include the projective version. The original proof of det_vandermonde is gone, as it is now derived from det_projVandermonde.

I've also defined a more general rectVandermonde form, where the rows have an arbitrary indexing type. Determinants don't make sense directly in this setting, but linear independence of rows still has a nice characterization, and this matters in the applications to coding/matroid theory and finite geometry, so it seemed reasonable to introduce this as the underlying definition.
Very nice! Do you plan to add more API about rectVandermonde later?
Yes, I've already written it. This was just a matter of limiting PR scope.
#22564 is one little thing that it needs.
